contentrichtext.text: {{about|the World War II military operation|the South African invasion of Angola|Operation Savannah (Angola)}} {{Refimprove|date=August 2007}} '''Operation Savanna''' (or '''Operation Savannah'''){{#tag:ref|Sources vary, but MRD Foot and the National Archive have the spelling ''Savanna''.{{sfn|Foot|1966|pp=157-159}}|group=lower-alpha}} was the first insertion of [[Special Operations Executive|SOE]] trained [[Free French]] paratroops into German-occupied France during [[World War II]]. This SOE mission, requested by the Air Ministry, was to ambush and kill as many pilots as possible of the Kampfgeschwader 100, a German Pathfinder formation stationed at [[Meucon]] airfield which spearheaded night raids on Britain. Setting off from an RAF Whitley on the moonlit{{sfn|NASA: Phases of the Moon}} night of 15 March 1941, five paratroops made a blind drop at midnight, landing some eight miles east of the town of [[Vannes]] (where the Pathfinder crew billeted), and five miles off target. The following day they discovered the pilots no longer commuted between Vannes and Meucon by bus, but had taken to travelling on an ad-hoc basis by cars. Hence the grand ambush and assassination had to be aborted. Seeking to gain something from the mission, Captain [[Georges Bergé]] instructed his men to disperse and go on general reconnaissance and meet at [[Sables d'Olonne]] at the end of the month for extraction by sea. One of the men was already missing and another failed to make the rendezvous. After several nights watching from the sand dunes, on 4/5 April, Bergé saw [[Geoffrey Appleyard]] of the SOE's [[Small Scale Raiding Force]] paddling ashore after launching from the submarine [[HMS Tigris (N63)|HMS ''Tigris'']]. Unfortunately, two other kayaks were damaged being launched so only Bergé and Forman could be extracted. {{ill|fr|Joël Le Tac|Joël Le Tac}} remained behind and made his way to a safehouse in Paris and continued as an SOE operative. The Free French paratroops went on to later form the [[1st Airborne Marine Infantry Regiment|French SAS]] and Bergé took part in some early raids in the near east, eventually rising to the rank of general. ==See also== *[[Operation Josephine B]] ==References== ;Footnotes {{reflist|group=lower-alpha}} ;Notes {{Reflist|2}} ;Bibliography *{{cite book | last = Foot | year = 1984 | first = M.R.D. | title = The Special Operations Executive 1940-1946 | authorlink = M.
